Award.AwardTitle: NRI: Small: Additive Manufacturing of Soft Robot Components with Embedded Actuation and Sensing

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to develop a new 3D printing/additive manufacturing process that will allow the direct fabrication from digital designs of integrated, multi-material devices such as soft robots with embedded actuators, sensors, and circuitry. The focus of the research will be (1) to design, prototype, characterize, optimize, and demonstrate the new process, and (2) to design, model, fabricate, and test an electromagnetic actuator and capacitive sensor made using the process. A testbed "robot printer" will be developed, along with control software and process design files. The research will require a number of technical and scientific advancements to provide the desired capabilities, including co-deposition of multiple materials in multi-layered patterns and formation of low-resistance electrical junctions.


If successful, the results of this research will lead to a new manufacturing process for soft robots, an emerging class of devices promising greater safety, better manipulation of delicate and irregular objects, the ability to squeeze through small openings in search and rescue operations, etc. The challenge of manufacturing soft robotic components that include a large number of distributed actuators, sensors, and associated circuitry can be economically approached by concurrent 3-D printing with two types of materials: one that is conductive for interconnects, and the other insulating and flexible. Today's 3-D printing works with one type or the other, but not both. Overcoming this limitation would be transformative and enable a wide range of sophisticated, active structures to be readily fabricated. Beyond robotics, applications of the research include active prosthetics, minimally-invasive surgical instruments, and smart implants, as well as stretchable and wearable electronics. Undergraduate and graduate students will be heavily involved, and a partnership with the Perot Museum of Nature and Science (Dallas, TX) to develop a semi-permanent display and live demonstrations will expose a wide public audience to 3-D printing and robotics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Additive manufacturing (AM, a.k.a. 3D printing) provides enormous versatility in terms of the ease of producing a new design and flexibility in the geometry of components that can be manufactured. A key challenge in AM is working with multiple materials of different types, such as electrically conductive and non-conductive materials, as AM methods tend to be optimized for one or the other type of material (e.g., metals or polymers, but not both). Such capability is essential to be able to simultaneously manufacture integrated active components such as sensors and electromagnetic actuators. Coupled with the ability to print soft, stretchable materials (e.g., elastomers), the capacity to work simultaneously with both conductive and non-conductive materials would allow the direct design and printing of fully functional soft-robotic components, optimized for a variety of tasks.

To address these challenges, this project investigated methods for expanding the capabilities of AM to allow for (a) simultaneous printing of polymer material together with high-current-capacity conductors (wires) and (b) printing very soft elastomeric materials. These efforts resulted in the development of FEAM (Fiber Encapsulations Additive Manufacturing) and TEAM (Thermoplastic Elastomer Additive Manufacturing). FEAM allows for simultaneous deposition of fibers and a polymer material that encapsulates the fiber during the printing of a layer of material in the AM process. The fiber material of interest was conductive wires. Methods for providing conductive connections between layers (laser soldering and deposition of electrically conductive polymer composite) were developed allowing for printing of fully 3D, electrical circuits, integrated into 3D printed parts. TEAM, on the other hand, prints soft elastomers by working with pelletized raw materials, rather than polymer fibers as is typical of fused deposition modeling 3D printers. Using this approach TEAM has been able to print the softest thermoplastic elastomers reported to date.

Using FEAM and TEAM, a range of AM capabilities were demonstrated. FEAM was used to 3D print devices such as push-button switches, a rheostat, and solenoids of various shapes. Coupling FEAM with integrated systems for depositing soft magnetic material, a fully functional solenoid actuator was fabricated directly on a single machine. Using TEAM, expandable components (hydraulic/pneumatic balloons) were fabricated as well as components with both hard and soft materials such as vibration isolators. Combining FEAM and TEAM, stretchable conductive circuits were printed. Taken together, these capabilities represent essential building blocks for 3D printing fully functional robotic components.

To assist with the development of new AM methods and engage developing engineers, many undergraduates were engaged to help develop methods and equipment alongside the graduate students and the postdoc working on the project. Additionally, several presentations, sponsored by the Perot Museum of Nature and Science, were made to the general public to discuss the future of AM and inspire a new generation of scientists and engineers.


Last Modified: 11/29/2017
Modified by: Adam L Cohen
